content.description: Start up good holds to a cool runnel/crack/pinch feature and carefully place a 2" cam. Somewhat tenuous layback moves lead to a bolt and even more tenuous laybacking. At the horizontal, place some thin gear and do a few more pumpy moves up and right to another bolt. Keep the pump in check as the holds get better and the feet get worse. As you approach the top, look for an exit up and right onto the easy slab. Scramble up to the top and reach down to clip the double-bolt anchor.
content.protection: 2 x 2" cams, yellow TCU or equivalent, purple TCU or equivalent. The gear on this pitch is not obvious, challenging to place, and somewhat spaced. It's not dangerous but kind of heads up.

content.description:
Dare Seize the Fire is a challenging and thrilling journey up the clean panel of thin seams in the middle of the Stripes Wall.

Begin on the first 2/3 of

Burning Bright

, then bust left along a seam. As the seam ends, place a small but solid TCU and engage a long, complex boulder problem up the streaked panel. Place more tricky gear at a pumpy stance, then do the final layback moves to the anchor at the top of the wall.

This route was established head-point style. The crux sequence is long, very beta intensive, and nearly impossible to suss on lead. A ground-up ascent would be impressive to say the least. Hypothetically, the small cam at the start of the crux would keep the climber off the ground, but it could be close.
content.protection: A set of cams from a purple TCU to hand-sized with doubles from 0.75" to 1.25".

content.description: Burning Bright is the obvious and longest line up the middle of the Stripes Wall. It has great rock quality and moves that are always difficult but never completely stopper.
content.protection: Standard rack to 2 inches. It is nice to have a couple of 0.3 sized pieces for the last 15 feet.
